awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research to Explore the Spatial/Temporal Statistical-Physical Structures of Rain in the Vertical Plane
awd_abstract_narration:
A good understanding of rain in time and space is important for improved public safety and productivity. With regard to public safety, this means better water control designs for reducing the impact of flooding from smaller urban to larger regional scales as well as for improved spatial and temporal warnings of flooding in order to reduce damage and fatalities. With regard to productivity in rural areas, such information has the potential for reducing the impacts of soil erosion through the better design of field run-off and water storage. In more urban areas, productivity depends in part upon good wireless communication. However, the advent of 5G wireless networks will be more subject to signal loss due to rain, a loss that also depends upon the largely unknown spatial structure of rainfall particularly above the ground. All of these improvements, however, depend upon the proper translation of radar measurements and numerical model outputs to many different scales. This in turn requires that radar measurements above the ground as well as numerical model products be correctly transferred to what appears at the surface where people live. This, then, is a central objective of this project.

More specifically with regard to the science, this project allows a more complete description of rain structure in a multi-dimensional context including height with the additional benefit of developing a better multi-dimensional understanding of drop interactions and evolution. Furthermore, the project is directed toward a more comprehensive investigation into the prevalence and the importance of statistical homogeneity in all three spatial dimensions as well as in time. Statistical homogeneity is important for the proper scaling of rainfall measurements, but, of course, not all rain is statistically homogeneous. However, it often appears that when the data are statistically heterogeneous, such data may be subdivided into statistically homogeneous sections which can then be properly treated analytically. This project develops this approach. In addition, wind tower measurements as well as simultaneous measurements between two 2DVD disdrometers will be used to explore further the reported deviations of drop fall speeds from their nominal terminal values both aloft and at the surface. This is potentially quite important for the proper understanding of the evolution of rain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was devoted to better understanding the statistical structures of rainfall. Previous awards were devoted primarily to understanding the space and time variability on scales too small to be revealed by radar and other common instruments; this study focused more on understanding the vertical variability of rainfall.

Radar observations determine information about the weather some distance above the surface; if a radar beam is sent out perfectly horizontally, it typically will run into a building or geographical feature before it gets too far, so typical radar scans involve looking slightly upward while the beam moves out horizontally.

Unfortunately, this means the information revealed by radar is coming from an elevation significantly above the surface (and higher the further from the radar facility). It generally has been assumed that the information revealed about the rainfall aloft is commensurate with the statistical behavior of rainfall at the surface -- but that isn't always accurate. On its fall to the ground, raindrops can break apart, collide with other drops, speed up, slow down, grow, and evaporate. The degree to which these changes alter the overarching rainfall statistics (e.g. total rain accumulations, erosional impact of the falling drops, etc.) has been largely unknown. This project was devoted to studying how different elements of the rain statistics varied with height by simultaneously measuring rain with instruments capable of measuring individual drop properties near the ground and a modest distance in the air -- through use of both instruments deployed on a tall tower and through vertically-pointing instruments that measure the rainfall as it falls toward the device.

In this study, we learned some important facts about rain and the clouds that can form rain.

First, we determined that rain sensing instrumentation often has poorly defined measurement accuracy and uncertainties. The vertically pointing device (called an MRR-Pro) has built in-assumptions regarding the turbulent wind-structures and wind/droplet interactions that don't hold up to careful scrutiny, and -- as such -- outputs from the instrument need to be re-interpreted to get useful data. In fact, this vertically pointing device doesn't seem to give useful information for heights up to several hundred meters above the surface. This meant that the desired direct-comparison between this instrument and the direct drop-sensing instruments alluded to earlier could not occur. We also worked to determine the accuracy and precision of commercial instruments specifically designed to measure rainfall a single drop at a time. We found that these devices, known as disdrometers, sometimes have the capability of measuring rain to more accuracy than previously expected -- which means that previous data-sets should be re-explored to determine the amount of useful information revealed from them.

A second set of outcomes from this study was that we learned quite a bit about how to answer the basic question "when are two observations the same vs. when are they different" within the context of measuring atmospheric particles like rain drops, cloud drops, or aerosol particles. This seemingly obvious question is surprisingly subtle. For example, if a measurement of 500 raindrops is made with 248 of them "small" and 252 of them "large" and a second measurement is made with 510 raindrops is made with 251 of them "small" and 259 of them "large", in a very real sense you have measured two different things -- the samples have differing numbers of drops, and the percentage of small vs. large -- albeit similar -- aren't exactly the same. However, the measurements are perhaps similar enough that one would want to claim that the measured rainfall could have been the same. Our work during this study developed new statistical tools to answer the question "are these measurements the same" with nuance, both in regards to size distributions (as illustrated with the example above) and in determining other statistics like determining if drops are spatially clustered in space or time. The statistical approaches developed have already been applied to cloud droplets, and we believe these approaches will continue to have broad applications within the atmospheric sciences in the years to come.

We continue to investigate the general themes of this project and believe that the data acquired during the life of the project will allow us to continue to learn more about the space and time variability of rainfall and cloud droplets.
